entry.title: Re: BUILD Work Zone - HTML5 Business Solutions vs HTML5 a...
entry.content:
Hello Jawad,

 

First of all, thank you for your answer. The links are helpful in clarifying how to implement this. My personal opinion, before having actually done it: it still seems very complicated, with a lot of manual adjustments in the MTA, which are always painful—apart from the destination setup. I know there's a BAS extension and some templates that might simplify the process for new apps.

However, I guess this topic still needs a lot of clarification, far beyond the manual and automatic refresh mechanisms we currently have in saas-approuter and HTML5 business solutions, respectively. One way to see that people are struggling to understand it and to use the HTML5 Business Solutions can be found in this interesting blog Simplifying HTML5 Content Consumption Across Subac... - SAP Community that is focusing more on the multi-tenant scenario (interested readers check out the comments as well).

However, I’d rather focus this thread on the single-tenant scenario—especially customers using Work Zone, not partners building products on top of BTP or Work Zone. Hopefully, this will become a useful resource in the future, potentially serving as an FAQ that could be included in a KBA.

I’m not sure exactly when HTML5 business solutions were introduced, but they seem relatively new (less than two years old)

1) First of all, does the single-tenant scenario means that we are restricted to use one or many BTP subaccount(s)? 

Based on Developing HTML5 Business Solutions as Content Providers | SAP Help Portal

This flow enables consumption of business solutions across subaccounts that belong to the same tenant. The SaaS provider deploys the business solution to its subaccount. The consumer subaccount creates the same destinations as the provider and runs the business solutions remotely, on the provider subaccount.

From my understanding the single tenant requires to have multiple subaccounts and wouldn't make sense if your apps are all in the same BTP subaccount. It's really unclear what does "same tenant" means in the sentence above. It is a global account? A directory? An IdP provider?

2) As a customer, what is the point of creating multiple subaccounts for different applications?

I’ve seen different BTP subaccounts being used to segregate environments (DEV, TEST, PROD), which makes sense. To segregate apps within a single environment, Cloud Foundry Spaces should serve that purpose well. So, what’s the point of creating a brand-new BTP subaccount for each business solution? That approach seems overly complex—especially considering how limited the “copy subaccount” feature in BTP currently is.

It only seems reasonable to go down that path if you have a solid infrastructure-as-code setup in place using Terraform, the BTP CLI, or similar tools. I understand that avoiding the need to refresh a Work Zone channel is a benefit, but the trade-off is a significantly more complex BTP landscape. Even if it’s automated, I’m not sure the added complexity is worth it.

In most customer scenarios, the person responsible for refreshing the Work Zone channel is likely not (and arguably shouldn’t be) the same person managing the BTP landscape setup—regardless of whether it's done manually or via IaC.

Lastly, you still have to manually create the HTML5 business solution in Work Zone, and you do that on the same screen where you would press the refresh button. I understand that a business solution only needs to be created once, but it’s once per app, which still amounts to a considerable effort.

3)  Resilience using HTML5 business solutions

I’m currently using saas_approuter, where the front end of all apps (except CAP-based ones) is hosted in a single BTP subaccount, meaning they’re bound to the same BTP region and cloud provider. This introduces a risk: if there’s a rare infrastructure issue in that region, the apps become unavailable since they’re not globally distributed.

Rare — but for context, in July 2025 alone, there were two major outages in Frankfurt (lasting days, not just hours).

So I wonder:

  • Is the HTML5 business solutions model intended to address resiliency?

  • Should I create multiple BTP subaccounts and use this approach to distribute the front end of apps globally?

  • Will the SAP-managed router automatically redirect traffic if a BTP region goes down?

4) BTP cockpit vs Common Data Model limitation

Based o "CommonDataModel in Section 3":

There are two different ways to integrate your application with SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition. You have to choose one way or the other and follow through. It’s currently not possible to mix the approaches. Both ways provide the same result. You can integrate your application with SAP Build Work Zone, standard edition through the SAP BTP cockpit or through Common Data Model. The tabs SAP BTP cockpit and Common Data Model provide detailed steps for each alternative way.

Where is the limitation exactly? Is it for the whole subscription in a single BTP subaccount? Is it on a site level where you can use BTP cockpit for a site and CDM for another one? Are you able to create multiple HTML5 business solutions in the same Work Zone instance?

5) Current usage of saas_approuter vs HTML5 business solutions

Could you share some numbers on the usage comparing both? Anyone reading this who is using HTML5 business solutions please share your experience.

6) Any plans to decomission saas_approuter? 

If yes, is it planned some sort of migration assistant?

7) Work zone limitations

Work zone has many limitations such as the number of apps in a role (2000) or the maximum number of items in a site (30000 which seems a look until you realize the number of locales multiplies the number of items you have). How are items counted in HTML5 business solutions? Will it count as a single item or it will count everything inside the cdm.json file just like it happens in the CDM3 content exposure of apps?

Thank you everyone who made it until here.

entry.title: Re: Unable to post 545 for by products via WHSCON idoc
entry.content:
WHSCON IDocs require proper batch split handling for by-products. Ensure that the E1EDL19 segment in the IDoc uses the ‘BAS’ qualifier for batch split items. The by-product must be reported as a new item, not as part of the original delivery item.

The error implies that the system expects 57,000 CAR of material 10035244 to be confirmed. If the IDoc doesn’t confirm the full quantity or splits it incorrectly, the system flags it as “open.” Check if the E1EDL24-LFIMG field (confirmed quantity) matches the expected value.

entry.title: Re: Double authorization while creating a sales order
entry.content:
Thank you for your question.

Best practice for your eCommerce solution with SAP digital payments add-on and SAP S/4HANA is to use one of the two APIs for Sales Order Management:
Sales Order (A2X) - S/4HANA Private Cloud and On-Premise
Sales Order (A2A) - S/4HANA Private Cloud and On-Premise

The same exists for S/4HANA Public Cloud:
Sales Order (A2X) - S/4HANA Public Cloud
Sales Order (A2A) - S/4HANA Public Cloud 

Scrolling down to the examples shows that in your use-case only the SAP Digital Payments card token and SAP Digital Payments authorization number is necessary to pass as payment plan item parameters.

"to_PaymentPlanItemDetails":[
{ "EPaytByDigitalPaymentSrvc"      : "token1",
  "AuthorizationByDigitalPaytSrvc" : "auth1"
  }]

 

The usage of iDocs is not supported automatically. That's why you are facing your mentioned issue.
But there are customers that were able to use the iDoc to map the SAP Digital Payments parameters into their S/4HANA and creating the card and authorization data properly in the underlying Sales Order.

I hope that helps!

entry.title: Re: Bottle Condition Type for PO - SAP

entry.title: Re: Decimal Notation conversion as per user setting
entry.content:
There is a bug in the FORM change_quantity. 
Eg: Please refer the below test scenario.

Results:

Therefore, the corrected one:
The below code will work for user selected decimal format on the selection screen. 

*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Form f_change_value
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& Change values based on user selected decimal format
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
*& -->  p1        text
*& <--  p2        text
*&---------------------------------------------------------------------*
FORM f_change_value USING u_delimiter TYPE c
                          u_separator TYPE c
                 CHANGING c_sample_value ##PERF_NO_TYPE.

  TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_number,
           text(30) TYPE c,
         END OF ty_number.

  DATA: lv_whole(30)         TYPE c,
        lv_decimal(30)       TYPE c,
        lv_strlen            TYPE i,
        lv_ndiv              TYPE i,
        lv_nmod              TYPE i,
        lv_flag              TYPE c,
        lv_temp              TYPE i,
        lv_previous_text(30) TYPE c,
        ls_number            TYPE ty_number,
        lt_number            TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_number.


  CLEAR: lt_number, ls_number, lv_temp, lv_flag, lv_previous_text, lv_whole, lv_decimal, lv_strlen, lv_ndiv, lv_nmod.

  SPLIT c_sample_value AT '.' INTO lv_whole
                                   lv_decimal.
  "Get value length without decimals
  lv_strlen = strlen( lv_whole ).
  "Divide length and get quotient
  lv_ndiv   = lv_strlen DIV 3.
  "Get remainder for length
  lv_nmod   = lv_strlen MOD 3.

  "Get remainder value length of first set of digits into table.
  IF lv_nmod IS NOT INITIAL.
    ls_number-text = lv_whole(lv_nmod).
    lv_temp = lv_nmod.
    APPEND ls_number TO lt_number.
    CLEAR: ls_number.
  ENDIF.

  "Do quotient number of times and append the 3 set digits into table.
  DO lv_ndiv TIMES.
    ls_number-text = lv_whole+lv_temp(3).
    lv_temp = lv_temp + 3.
    APPEND ls_number TO lt_number.
    CLEAR: ls_number.
  ENDDO.
  CLEAR: lv_whole.

  LOOP AT lt_number ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_number>).
    IF lv_flag IS INITIAL.
      "Assign first set of digits into variable
     lv_whole = <fs_number>-text.
      "remove spaces
      CONDENSE lv_whole NO-GAPS.
      lv_previous_text = lv_whole.
      lv_flag = abap_true.
    ELSE.
      "concatenate remaining 3 set digits
      CONCATENATE lv_previous_text <fs_number>-text INTO lv_whole
                                          SEPARATED BY u_delimiter.
      lv_previous_text = lv_whole.
    ENDIF.
    c_sample_value = lv_whole.
  ENDLOOP.
  IF lv_decimal IS NOT INITIAL.
    CONCATENATE c_sample_value lv_decimal INTO c_sample_value
                                  SEPARATED BY u_separator.
  ENDIF.
ENDFORM.

entry.title: Re: Double authorization while creating a sales order
entry.content: Please be aware that the customer is using SAP Digital Payments. Here, it is mandatory to use the authorization number from SAP Digital Payments and NOT from the PSP. The same holds true for the card token.

entry.title: Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release
entry.content:
Welcome to the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release! The next release to help businesses unlock agility, intelligence, and resilience through Cloud ERP.

If you prefer watching rather than reading, you are welcome to check out my product update video, where I guide you through the content with my virtual twin.  

 

Figure 1: Check out my top highlights of the release in this video. 

The evolution of business capabilities via SAP Business AI will be a significant part of my personal release highlights. The arrival of SAP BDC, our Business Data Cloud (BDC) within our flagship ERP product SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition marks another highlight and brings the SAP flywheel to life.

And to be honest, I am particularly proud of the extensions we are now providing, built on the three-system landscape architecture, as the demand for more localizations have been articulated by many customers.

Over the years, we witnessed steady, linear growth that reflected our commitment to consistency and quality and a growing business scope. The new system architecture allowed us to enhance the scalability and flexibility for our customers, making it more adaptable. This shift was more than just a technical upgrade; it represented a transformation in the way our customers could approach own developments, deployment, and expansion and allowed our customers to better meet the needs of a growing user base and last-mile-individualization demand.  Building on this architecture, we now add new capabilities step-by-step.

 

Configuration localization tool now generally available

We are happy to announce the general availability of the configuration localization tool. This feature embedded in SAP Central Business Configuration is designed to streamline the creation of tailored customer local versions for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition for around further 160 countries and regions on top of the 60 standard local versions.

This tool is easy to use, empowering partners and customers to create new local versions efficiently. It provides localized configuration for a selected target country or region based on the settings of a source country or region - currently Germany.  This tool ensures localized configurations are generated consistently and life cycle compliant, a further project using available extensibility options can adopt to specific demands.

Figure 2: System screenshot

 

 

 

 

 

 

For further reference, you are welcome to check out my blog post on parallel line as the next evolution of our public cloud ERP product journey.

 

Figure 3: Demo video

 

 

 

 

 

The general availability of the configuration localization tool opens the door for businesses to quickly and reliably expand into new markets with consistent configuration standards and tailored business processes.

Before we jointly investigate extended business capabilities, let’s explore, how SAP’s flywheel, combining fully integrated cloud applications, mission-critical data, and embedded AI, equipping enterprises to respond to macro-economic volatility, is coming to life.

 

BDC integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and initial list of data products

SAP S/4HANA Cloud PCE now supports Business Data Cloud (BDC) integration, offering a robust and scalable framework that enables seamless data exchange between SAP systems and external platforms. The solution is designed to unlock new levels of operational efficiency, agility, and insight across the enterprise.

BDC integration allows organizations to establish reliable connections between SAP S/4HANA Cloud PCE and a variety of external systems and databases. By automating the flow of data across these environments, companies can significantly reduce manual effort, minimize the risk of error, and shift their focus from routine maintenance to strategic action. The result is a more connected enterprise build on advanced analytics and processing capabilities, while maintaining the flexibility to work with a broader digital ecosystem.

At the core of this integration lies a rich and growing suite of data products, with an initial offering of approximately 36 available for use across departments and industries. These include financial accounting data that covers general ledger entries, accounts receivable and payable, and bank statements; sales and distribution data to improve order management and fulfillment; and material management data that supports real-time inventory control and procurement decisions. The human resources data offering helps manage employee information and recruiting metrics, while Customer Relationship Management (CRM) Insights allow organizations to better understand and serve their customers.

Additionally, businesses can leverage SAP Ariba Supplier Management profiles to strengthen vendor relationships, production planning records to enhance manufacturing efficiency, and retail and logistics analytics to refine distribution strategies. Project management metrics offer greater visibility into timelines, budgets, and outcomes, while compliance and audit reports help organizations stay proactive in meeting regulatory standards.

These data products collectively form a foundational layer for a next level of transformation. By combining them with BDC integration, organizations gain the ability to select and customize the data flows that are most relevant to their specific goals and processes and future-proof their operations via a truly connected, insight-driven enterprise. You will find more information here. 

 

What is on top of my business feature and AI list?

Simplify asset accounting

In the Finance domain, we’re elevating the user experience with AI-powered innovations that reshape how fixed asset data is interpreted and managed. A standout feature of this release is the introduction of AI-generated explanations for fixed asset key figures.

These insights, delivered in natural language, help users clearly understand the origins and calculations behind critical values such as depreciation and net book value. This capability simplifies interpretation, allowing users to grasp financial figures and value changes more quickly, which enhances productivity and reduces the time required for recurring financial tasks.

Additionally, we've already delivered AI-assisted asset master data creation, allowing users to enter data using simple conversational commands. This reduces the effort and time required for data entry and onboarding, while improving accuracy and data governance through intuitive, user-friendly interfaces.

Get more details here.

Figure 4: AI-assisted explanation of fixed asset key figures

 

 

 

 

 

SAP Business AI is central to these improvements, providing detailed explanations and support that facilitate better decision-making and enhance user satisfaction.

This release aligns with SAP's commitment to delivering efficient and user-centric solutions in asset accounting.

 

AI-assisted processing of incoming quality certificates with SAP Document AI

With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, we are introducing an innovation that brings generative AI directly into the core of quality management: SAP Document AI. This powerful, AI-driven feature automates and streamlines the handling of incoming quality certificates, unlocking efficiency gains for our customers.

SAP Document AI accelerates the processing of supplier quality certificates by extracting relevant information from documents—whether paper or digital—and seamlessly integrating it into SAP workflows. This innovation reduces manual effort, shortens processing times, and lowers the risk of human error. Quality technicians are freed from repetitive tasks, allowing them to focus on more strategic and value-adding activities. As a result, companies can release stock faster, reduce inspection-related production delays, and achieve overall improvements in throughput.

Accuracy and reliability are also improved. By automatically matching certificates with system records and updating their status, SAP Document AI ensures that no document goes missing and that compliance is upheld throughout the process. Intelligent error handling provides added resilience and trust in the system.

One of the most powerful aspects of this solution is its seamless integration into the SAP S/4HANA Cloud experience. Delivered as a ready-to-use capability, SAP Document AI requires no custom development, offering customers an immediate path to value and a faster return on investment.

Figure 5: Quality management AI certificate

 

 

 

 

 

As we continue to embed AI, data, and automation into the fabric of our ERP offering, SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition stands as a foundation for smarter, more agile operations. The introduction of SAP Document AI is just one example of how we are helping our customers future-proof their business, drive continuous improvement, and lead with innovation.

 

Beta: AI-assisted smart solution for situations

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release brings a new dimension of intelligence to the user experience with the introduction of the AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home. Currently available in beta testing, this innovative feature simplifies the resolution of business-critical situations by dynamically guiding users through resolution steps, reducing complexity, and improving the quality of decision-making. The context-aware recommendations and outcomes that are both trustworthy and relevant.

This smart solution leverages generative AI to adapt the user interface in real time, presenting timely insights and suggested actions tailored to the specific business context. Designed to support fast, informed decisions, it transforms traditionally manual and multi-step tasks into a seamless, click-efficient experience.

Le’s make it tangible: In a classical ERP environment, a sales representative receives a notification for a sales quotation to expire soon. In a conventional workflow, the user would open the situation, navigate to the quotation, manually edit the details, save the changes, and then return to resolve the situation. With the AI-assisted solution, these steps are consolidated into a single, streamlined flow—demonstrating how user effort is minimized while responsiveness is maximized. Watch the example in this video.

Accessible from the SAP S/4HANA Cloud homepage, the solution enables situation handling in just a few clicks, a dynamic cards concept brings key information and associated actions together.

Join the SAP beta testing for the latest AI-assisted user experience features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. For more details, visit the Get Involved Early page to register and contribute to the evolving landscape of AI-driven business processes. 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud now supports Business Data Cloud (BDC) integration, offering a robust and scalable framework that enables seamless data exchange between SAP systems and external platforms. This integration is designed to unlock new levels of operational efficiency, agility, and insight across the enterprise.

As companies look to future-proof their operations, the integration of Business Data Cloud with SAP S/4HANA Cloud offers a powerful opportunity to move toward a truly connected, insight-driven enterprise. With this innovation, SAP continues to support customers in building intelligent, resilient, and agile business models.

 

SAP Activate innovations

Also, our agile activation methodology, SAP Activate, receives further improvements in both, the content and user experience—making project execution more intelligent and accessible.

With this release, Joule capabilities are now live in the SAP Activate road map viewer for all users, starting with the SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Cloud ERP Private implementation road maps.

Joule brings AI-assisted support directly into the project guidance experience, helping users find the right assets faster and navigate complex tasks more intuitively. Additional content will be added in the coming weeks, expanding Joule’s reach to even more road maps. Learn more in this blog post by Chandan Gurav.

To further streamline onboarding, we’ve also refreshed the initial experience in the SAP Activate road map viewer. A new visual design, guided entry points, and onboarding assets built into the home screen help new users get started with greater ease. For more details on this improved experience, see this blog post by Ana Goetze.

Lastly, we’ve launched a dedicated provisioning road map for SAP Business Suite packages, now available in the road map viewer. This new asset provides targeted guidance to support a smooth setup experience. You can explore the details in this blog post by Adnette Kamugisha.

These updates mark an important step in delivering a more intelligent and user-friendly implementation experience—designed to support customers and partners from day one.

 

GenAI-driven extensibility assistant

With the 2508 release, the introduction of the genAI-driven extensibility assistant marks a significant evolution in how custom fields and business logic are managed. By embedding generative AI into the extensibility framework, the process of adapting the system becomes faster, more intuitive, and more transparent.

The assistant simplifies the creation of custom fields, allowing organizations to respond to evolving requirements with agility and precision. This removes the dependency on complex development tasks and enables quicker adaptations to support new data capture and reporting needs. AI also supports the discovery of relevant business contexts, helping to align custom fields with underlying business processes from the outset, improving consistency and relevance in system behavior as changes are introduced.

Transparency is further enhanced through intelligent usage analysis. Understanding where specific fields or logic are deployed across the system supports better governance and more efficient change management. This visibility is essential for maintaining control over system customizations while enabling ongoing innovation.

To support accurate and efficient data entry, the assistant also helps identify relevant value help views. This improves user interactions and contributes to high-quality data standards across the system. For more advanced extensibility scenarios, the assistant streamlines the activation of business scenarios with context-aware recommendations. Configurations can be fine-tuned to operational needs with greater confidence and less manual effort.

Furthermore, the GenAI-driven assistant aids in locating the appropriate Business Add-In (BAdI) for specific use cases. This ensures that enhancements are both technically sound and aligned with system architecture best practices—delivering functional flexibility without compromising system integrity.

Figure 6: Extensibility Assistant

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

My summary

The SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release delivers tons of innovations, across platform, extension concepts, business feature and SAP Business AI. From finance and quality management to global rollout capabilities. Pick what you like and let me know what your personal highlights are.

I invite you to explore the deeper business and industry-specific innovations in the upcoming blogs. Be sure to visit our community page to connect with our team of experts, ask your questions, and share your feedback.

Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay current with future updates.

Feel free to follow me at BeSchulze in the community and on LinkedIn to not miss any updates. 

Let’s keep advancing together—towards a smarter, more connected ERP future.

Yours,

Bert

entry.title: SAP Workzone Local Entry Point stopped working
entry.content:
Issue Summary
On Thursday, 24/07/2025, both CEP and LEP services stopped working for our team.

  • CEP services: Resumed functioning sometime this week.

  • LEP services: Still not working as expected.

Current Behavior

  • The LEP site loads, we can see the Catalog and launch apps via  Classic App finder.

  • However, no Spaces or Workpages are visible or accessible.

  • Attempted GraphQL calls from Workzone targeting the menus (spaces/workpages) for LEP (siteId: "default") fail.

Technical Details

mymtxapp-approuter.cfapps.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/cp.portal/cep/content/v1?query=%7Bmenu(siteId%3A%22default%22)%7D 

{
  "errors": [
    {
      "message": "You are not authorized to access this resource or the site does not contain the needed roles",
      "path": [
        "menu"
      ],
      "extensions": {
        "statusCode": "FORBIDDEN_ERROR"
      }
    }
  ],
  "data": null

This error is a bit misleading as there is only one role collection and it is working cause we can see the catalog

nothing has changed, i even tried the running https://github.com/cap-js/incidents-app/blob/saas-lep/workzone/cdm.json and no cigar

Request

  • Could someone please advise on next steps to resolve the issue with LEP so Spaces and Workpages show up again?

@SAPSupport @IrisSasson @FabianBerr @rupambhatta

entry.title: Re: Intercompany Stock Transfer (1P9) in S/4HANA Cloud ERP, Public Edition
entry.content:
@LeTrongTrung thanks for the question. Yes, you can schedule a background job via APP Schedule Inbound Delivery Creation (F2798) as an alternative instead of the manual creation of inbound deliveries via APP  Inbound Deliveries for Purchase Orders (VL34) when you have specified a suitable confirmation control key in the stock transport order. 

Meanwhile, I did not quite cross check this with OP & Private but this general function is probably also available.

entry.title: Re: Session Details not updated in FF Log
entry.content:
All,

We have found the issue, it is due to missing of function module GRIA_SPM_MAINTENANCE in ECC systems.

The below note explains about the function module and dependent objects , which is really helpful.

3318927 - Functional change for Firefighter Session Management (GRCPINW).

Thanks and Regards,

entry.title: Re: Amazon Punchout integration with SAP S/4HANA Public C...
entry.content:
Hi @aman_mittal,

Thank you for your question.

Below are my confirmations based on SAP’s official documentation for SAP S/4HANA Public Clou Edition:

  • S/4 Cloud does not maintain supplier catalogs internally. Punch-out catalog experiences rely on external supplier punch-out (OCI or cXML) via SAP Business Network or supplier websites. See Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 for further information.
  • SAP currently supports punch-outs primarily through SAP Ariba Buying for example, for major catalogs integrated with Business Network.
  • There is no SAP-delivered integration or setup guide specifically for Amazon PunchOut and S/4HANA Public Cloud via CPI.
  • If you have an Amazon-provided guide, it may need custom translation via CPI or middleware to convert into OCI/cXML messages accepted by S/4HANA Cloud.

I hope this provides more clarity on the available possibilities.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Can S-price materials not be posted to UMB when runni...
entry.content:
Yes, why you are not able to change it because, SAP assumes that price differences for standard price materials should always go to UMB, as part of its inventory valuation principles. The reason code only influences the debit side (PRD), not the credit side. The credit posting to UMB is hardcoded in the valuation logic and tied to transaction key UMB in OBYC and there’s no standard enhancement point that allows you to override UMB with a different transaction key based on reason code.

If you still want to achieve this requirement, you can consider either with FI substitution or BAdI, but there are certain advantages and disadvantages in both these custom validations.

The advantages of going with FI substitution rule are no coding required for basic substitutions. Can be used to derive or replace field values during document posting. The disadvantage is FI substitutions are more effective in financial documents than inventory movements. Incorrect substitutions can lead to posting inconsistencies or audit issues. May not trigger during MR22, depending on how the valuation logic is executed.

With regard to MB_DOCUMENT_BADI, the advantages are it can be used to redirect G/L accounts dynamically based on custom logic (e.g., reason code, material type). It supports complex enhancements which are not possible via substitution rules. Coming to disadvantages, incorrect implementation can cause stock inconsistencies, system dumps, or data corruption. SAP Notes like 1315985 and 1284654 warn about inconsistencies if not handled carefully. Finally, this BAdI doesn’t support stopping the posting with error messages directly

entry.title: Decoupling Strategies for HTTP-Based Integrations in SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
In many integration scenarios, your sender communicates over HTTP and expects a synchronous response within a strict timeout window. Meanwhile, your integration flow may involve asynchronous processing that takes significantly longer.

Recently our integration partner expressed a concern that their timeout cannot exceed 3 seconds, but processing at our side took over a minute. In such case you have a few options how to decouple the integration flow, respond to your sender and continue processing the request:

  • JMS queue
  • Event-based platform
  • SOAP adapter
  • DataStore

JMS queue

Recommended and most common option

  • Use case: Ideal when you want to immediately acknowledge the HTTP request and process it asynchronously

  • How it helps: You can push the message to a JMS queue quickly, send an HTTP 200/202 response back to the sender within their timeout, and continue processing in a separate flow that consumes from the queue

  • Benefits: Reliable, durable, retry mechanisms, and native to CPI

  • Limitation: Certain number of JMS queues. Especially if you have AS2 integration partners, you can quickly run out of your available JMS queues

Event-Based Platform

Stand-alone software products like SAP Event Mesh or Kafka

  • Use case: When you're operating in an event-driven architecture and want to loosely couple components

  • How it helps: You can publish an event to a broker, respond quickly to the sender, and let a separate consumer handle the processing

  • Benefits: Scales well, decouples systems further, fits microservice/event-driven design

  • Limitation: May be a little of overkill for a single-use scenario, complex setup and requires integration with Event Mesh or external brokers

SOAP adapter

You create a small helper iflow with HTTP Sender, where you just provide answer to the Sender and call your processing iflow via SOAP adapter.

This approach requires modifying the sender configuration of your processing iFlow to accept SOAP requests. You’ll also need to configure the SOAP adapter to allow asynchronous behavior.


This settings ensures that the caller receives immediate response and processing continues further in more of an asynchronous way. 

  • Use case: Simple calls, where we can easily transform the HTTP call into a SOAP call. That also requires converting any incoming payload into XML

  • How it helps: SOAP can work in both sync and async behavior, based on the SOAP Sender adapter setting 

  • Benefits: Quick-win solution for simple calls, doesn't require queues, persistence or dedicated software

  • Limitation: Large payloads in non-XML format will be complicated to handle

DataStore

A fall-back option, not really recommended, but still usable if above options are not for you

  • Use case: When you don't have access to JMS queues or Event Mesh, and you're dealing with low-to-medium volume messages that can tolerate delayed, batch-style processing.

  • How it helps: You persist the incoming message to the CPI Datastore, respond immediately to the HTTP sender (e.g., with HTTP 202 Accepted), and then use a separate, scheduled iFlow to retrieve the message from the Datastore and continue processing asynchronously.

  • Benefits: Provides basic persistence and decoupling, useful for non-critical or internal scenarios.

  • Limitation: No built-in retry mechanism, requires manual polling logic via scheduler, not suited for high-throughput or time-sensitive processing.

As we can see, all above solutions have their pros and cons. Ideally, the best option would be to achieve this at the HTTP adapter itself. Nevertheless, HTTP adapter is synchronous by design and there is no configuration which could change this.

We also explored workarounds such as routing the HTTP request through a parallel or sequential multicast before forwarding it to the processing iFlow. However, this approach did not reliably solve the issue.

I will be grateful for any tip or insight on this topic, solving the issue with HTTP adapter or in any other way.

entry.title: Re: Multiple billing documents that contain items from ju...
entry.content:
Hi @Kaito2 

Based on the answer @Chuma  provided, I have checked SAP Help and KBA documentation for SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition. I have a similar finding that confirmed what was said.

However, to replicate the desired partial-billing behaviour of the Fiori app via API, here is my recommended approach:

  1. On your side (middleware or integration layer), split the delivery items or quantities manually into separate sets.
  2. Make separate API calls to API_BILLINGDOCUMENT_SRV, each time with a payload referencing the delivery items and quantities for that partial billing. You can approach this by carrying out the following:
      • Make call number 1: delivery “DLV123”, items 10 and 20
      • Then make call number 2: same delivery “DLV123”, item 30

Each of these calls will produce a separate billing document as you intended.

The following Billing Document SRV link will provide you with further details.

While it's not as seamless as the Fiori app, this is the only fully supported method in Public Cloud.

Best regards,

Chris

entry.title: Re: Generate EAM log for Firefighter sessions with no act...
entry.content: No activity means zero log, hence nothign need to be checked by the controller as nothing happend. GRC collects the log which was generated between the logon and the calculated logoff timestamp. It is not designed to decide anything, hence it is a simple count. If the number of logs are above 0, then logs will be generated irrespectively of 4020. If the count is 0, then 4020 came into the picture and then WF generated or not.

entry.title: User-Defined Net or Gross Value Transfer to Service Confirmation in Spare Part Procurement Scenario
entry.content:
Overview

A new SSCUI app, "Copy Procurement Price to Service Confirmation", has been introduced to enable users to choose whether the net or gross value should be transferred to the Service Confirmation.

By selecting the ‘Copy Net Price’ checkbox in the SSCUI, the net value is transferred. If the checkbox is not selected, the gross value will be transferred which is the default functionality. This setting applies to the specific transaction types in both Service Order (SV01) and Fixed Price Service Order (SV02).

Purpose

The solution will cover both service confirmation business scenarios. The service part procurement scenario, where the service confirmation is created as a follow-up from the service order. As well as the external service scenario, where the service confirmation is created from the service entry sheet workflow.

The behaviour of the value transfer depends on the item-based accounting status:

  • When item-based accounting is active:
    • The value is initially copied from the Purchase Order when the Service Confirmation is created.
    • Upon Supplier Invoice creation, the value in the Service Confirmation is updated from the invoice.
  • When item-based accounting is not active:
    • If a Supplier Invoice exists, its value is transferred to the Service Confirmation.
    • If not, the value is taken from the Purchase Order.

Scenario 1: Creation of the Service Confirmation

When a Service Confirmation is created, the item price is copied from the related Purchase Order item.

Process Steps

  1. Create a Service Order using the relevant service part item.
  2. In the Service Order edit screen, navigate to the Price Details section and add the Price Element ‘Manual Price (PMP0)’ with a sample value such as 200, as applicable.

                          

      3.  Release the Service Order.

      4.  Retrieve the Purchase Requisition number from the Transaction History.

         

       5.  Create a Purchase Order by referencing the requisition number.

       6. In the Purchase Order:

    • Go to  Item Details > Conditions.  
    • Set the condition type PMP0(Manual Gross Price) to a sample value, such as 200 USD and verify the corresponding net value is updated accordingly.

                    

    • TTX1 (Tax) = 10.00 USD (assumed)→ Gross value becomes 210.00 USD.       

    • Save and verify that the Purchase Order is created.

      7. Create a Goods Receipt.

      8. Create a Service Confirmation.

      9. Create a Supplier Invoice.

Expected Outcome

  • A Price Element with ID PMP0 is created in the Service Confirmation:
    • 200.00 USD(Net Value) if  'Copy Net Price' is enabled.
    • 210.00 USD(Gross value) if 'Copy Net Price' is disabled.

This confirms the successful copying of the price from the Purchase Order Item to the Service Confirmation based on the configuration.

Scenario 2: Release of Supplier Invoice

When a Supplier Invoice is released, the Service Confirmation item value is updated based on the invoice.

Process Steps

  1. Follow steps 1 to 7 from Scenario 1.

 

      2. Open the Incoming Invoice transaction.

    • Check “Calculate Tax”.
    • Set the tax dropdown to a suitable value, such as “V0”, based on your business requirements.
    • Under PO Reference, select “Purchase Order/Scheduling Agreement” and enter the PO number.
    • For item 1, change the Amount to 500.00 USD (net value) and press Enter.
    • Tax Amount should be 25.00 USD (assumed).
    • In the Basic Data section, enter 525.00 USD in the Amount field (gross value) which should bring the Balance
    • Save and verify the Supplier Invoice.

 

      3. Create a Service Confirmation.

Expected Outcome

  • A Price Element with ID PMP0 is created in the Service Confirmation:
    • 500.00 USD(Net Value) if 'Copy Net Price'  is enabled.
    • 525.00 USD(Gross Value) if 'Copy Net Price'  is disabled.

This confirms the successful copying of the price from the Supplier Invoice to the Service Confirmation based on the configuration.

entry.title: Server Ping Monitoring through SAP Solution Manager
entry.content:
Hello SAP,

We are planning to implement Server Ping Monitoring through SAP Solution Manager (SolMan) as part of our proactive infrastructure health checks and availability monitoring strategy.

Objective:

The primary goal is to enable real-time monitoring of server availability by performing regular ICMP ping checks. This will help us detect unresponsive servers at an early stage, allowing for timely intervention and reduced service disruption.

Requirements:

  • Monitoring Scope: All critical application servers within the SAP landscape.
  • Check Frequency: Pings should be scheduled at regular intervals to continuously verify the availability of the target servers.
  • Alert Mechanism: In the event of a failed ping response, SolMan should trigger alerts via email and/or SMS to the relevant support teams as per the configured alert directory.

Request for Support:

We would appreciate your guidance on the following points:

  1. Is this functionality supported in SAP Solution Manager?
  2. Are there any predefined templates or configurations available for setting up server ping monitoring within SolMan?
  3. What are the recommended steps to proceed with implementation?

Your support and insights would be greatly appreciated as we move forward with this initiative.

Looking forward to your response


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Server Ping Monitoring through SAP Solution Manager
entry.content:
Hello team,

Thank you for reaching out with your inquiry about implementing Server Ping Monitoring with SAP Solution Manager. I'm pleased to provide guidance regarding the functionality and setup you're considering.

  1. Functionality in SAP Solution Manager: Server Ping Monitoring can be addressed using System Monitoring capabilities within SAP Solution Manager. This allows you to monitor the availability of your critical application servers and includes options for alerting when a server is unresponsive.

  2. Templates and Configurations: SAP Solution Manager provides predefined templates and configuration options for system monitoring. Specifically, System Monitoring and Advanced Monitoring features enable URL and ICMP ping checks to verify server availability.

  3. Implementation Steps: To proceed with setting up server ping monitoring, you’ll need to follow these general steps:

    • Configure the System Monitoring setup, including identifying target servers and defining the ping check parameters.
    • Set up alert mechanisms via the Alert Directory to ensure notifications are sent to the relevant support teams through email or SMS.

For further detailed information and guidance, please refer to the official documentation available on the SAP Help Portal. Here are some useful links:

  • SAP Solution Manager - System Monitoring Overview
  • SAP Solution Manager - Advanced Monitoring
  • Main concept of monitoring tools Learning

You can test running SOLMAN_SETUP / Application operations / System Monitoring  where you select the template and will enable not only availability monitoring, but also other metric categories as performance, configuration and exception.

For further prerequisite insights, review 2512142 - Monitoring and alerting: prerequisites to run System Monitoring correctly 

Best regards,
Luis Salazar

entry.title: Streamline invoice dispute with generative AI invoice error classification
entry.content:
The business impact of invoice rejection

Let’s face it, getting your invoice rejected is a pain. Not only because you need to find out what went wrong, but also because it means starting the process all over again, further delaying payment. And you’re not the only one experiencing pain. Ardent Partners’ 2024 trends shows that the invoice exception rate is consistently pretty high across most industries with a quarter of all invoices (25.5%) flagged for an exception. On the bright side, firms that use procure-to-pay technologies fare much better, with an exception rate of around 10%. SAP Business Network confirms this trends and even pushes it further, with an 11% of invoice exception rate in 2023 now down to 7% in June 2025! 

But even with technology that helps streamlining buyer-seller collaboration, there are many reasons that can lead your invoice to be rejected: price discrepancies, tax miscalculations, quantity errors, reconciliation with PO, paperwork missing, formatting of invoice reference… So the fastest way to solve the issue is to clearly understand the reasons for rejection. The problem there is that invoice rejections from external invoice processing system comprises of multiple rejection reasons in a semi structured format. These rejections offer a mix of user entered input and system generated rejection reasons, leading to a great effort in deciphering where the mistake lies.

 

Intelligent invoice error categorization and summarization

SAP Business Network introduces a new feature offering suppliers the option to use a generative AI functionality to classify and categorize the comments from the buyer's systems and users, so it will be clearer to them why their invoice was rejected. Using this functionality, the suppliers on SAP Business Network can:
• summarize and categorize the invoice rejection reasons,
• view this classified output on the invoice details page.
The rejection messages are segregated into different categories using a Large Language Model. Suppliers can use this classified information to get precise information on rejection details (Line number, Part number, Description), rejection category (user rejected, system rejected), rejection level (Generic, Header, Line) and and the Invoice field associated with the rejection, which helps them to identify and avoid recurring issues.

Watch the video

To view the categorized message, follow these steps:
1. Log in to your SAP Business Network account as a supplier.
2. Open a rejected invoice, either from the homepage or from the invoice tab.
3. Select the Simplify errors with AI toggle in the header of the invoice.

Activate the feature

The functionality is disabled by default for all the users and admins. A supplier administrator must enable the generative AI functionality for invoice in SAP Business Network by following these simple steps:
1. Log in to your SAP Business Network account as a supplier.
2. Go to Account Settings > Settings > Generative AI .
3. Select Invoice and then click Apply.

Other features enhanced by generative AI are also available for the administrator to activate from the same screen. 

Curious about more features or looking for information on how to maximize the use of your supplier account? Make sure to visit our dedicated page SAP Business Network for Suppliers | SAP Community.

entry.title: Re: CDS View I_GLACCOUNTHIERARCHY is empty in SAP S/4HANA...
entry.content:
There is some chance that you don't have the necessary rights on the data. There is an Access Control called I_GLAccountHierarchy linked with this CDS view using authorization object F_UNI_HIER.

This kind of issue is quite common and sometimes hard to figure it out as no errors will show up in SU53 or similar functionality and the authorization happens implicitly. Keep in mind the access condition here using the data on column HRYID and a fixed condition on the other authorization object fields. 

HRYID, HRYTYPE = 'FSVN', ACTVT = '03'

(snapshot taken in S/4HANA 2023 on-prem)

entry.title: Time Valuation to Allocate a Default of 8 Hours to TOIL for Saturdays, Regardless of Hours Worked
entry.content:
As a Time Management consultant, we come across many client requirements on a daily basis. Some of the requirements can be solved using standard solutions, while some need custom solutions. Recently, I got a requirement from client in Spain that they want to get a default 8Hours of time to TOIL Account ,  where if an employee works on Saturday which is either less than 8hours or more than 8hours , Default 8hours should be sent to TOIL account so later that employees can use that hours to take a comp-off leave as per the Spain legal regulations

Scenario: When employees work on Saturdays (Which is a non-working day as per work schedule), a default of 8 hours should be credited to their comp-off account, also known as the TOIL account, regardless of the actual hours worked on that day.

Steps to Achieve the Scenario:

To Achieve this scenario, In total I have configured a total of 3 valuations which are described below:

Valuation 1: Generate a fixed 8 hours within the specified time type group

 

Let's Decode Valuation 1:

This valuation is configured to get a fixed 8Hours into a time type group which will help us to carry those hours into Saturday Comp-off account on the recorded day .

Valuation Type: Create Time Record (This valuation is used to fetch the time specified within start and end time fields.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Time Type Group Above: Default 8HRS serves as the above group, which is used to store the total hours of start and end time which means 8hours as per the mentioned timings. The category of the above group is taken as calculated time, which is used to store the total hours. (Refer to screenshot 2 above)

Valuation 2: Identifying the hours worked on Saturday (Either of any hour recorded on saturday)

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Let's Decode Valuation 2:

This valuation is used to fetch hours worked on Saturday which is a non-working day in my case as per work schedule.

Valuation Type: Filter Input Groups (This valuation is used to filter input groups based on given time record criteria.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Input Group: The Recorded Working Time group, used as working time, is assigned with my attendance types through which employee records time in timesheet (Refer to screenshot 2 above).

Time Records Filter: The Working Hours Saturday group is mainly used to specify Saturdays as non-working days according to my work schedule. I have specifically mentioned Saturdays and non-working days for greater precision. (Refer to screenshot 3 above)

Time Type Group Below: The Working Hours on Saturday group is used as the below group in above case, as the hours fetched by the filter group will always fall in this group. The time category of the below group is used as calculated time, which is mainly used to store the filtered hours. (Refer to screenshot 4 above)

Valuation 3: Compare Saturday Working hours, If more than 0 then route to above group regardless of hours recorded , which redirects the hours to TOIL Account


 

 

Let's Decode Valuation 3:

This valuation is designed to assess any time worked on Saturday and, if applicable, redirect the default 8 hours to the TOIL account. If no time is worked on Saturday, then no hours will be allocated to TOIL.

Valuation Type: Compare threshold with comparison group to route input (This valuation is used to compare the comparison group with a threshold and redirect the hours to either the above or below group.) (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Input Group: The Default 8HRS group is the result group from first valuation mentioned above, which stores the default 8 hours. (Refer to Valuation 1)

Comparison Group: The Working Hours on Saturday group is taken from the second valuation above, which records hours worked on Saturdays. (Refer to Valuation 2)

Threshold Group: In this scenario, I want to send 8 hours to the TOIL account for anyone who works on Saturday, regardless of the actual hours worked. Therefore, I have set the threshold value to 0, meaning that if the hours exceed 0, the default input group will be sent to TOIL. (Refer to screenshot 1 above)

Time Type Group Above: The Saturday Default 8HRS into TOIL Group is used to store the hours and directly transfer them to the TOIL account, which employees can use to take time off. (Refer to screenshot 2 above)

Let's test this in timesheet:

Before Recording Time on Saturday

As you can see, before recording, there are no hours recorded on Saturday, and therefore, no hours have been sent to TOIL account which is also called as comp-off account.

After Recording Time on Saturday

In the screenshot above, you can see that I have recorded 1 hour on Saturday; then the default of 8 hours is sent to TOIL. In the TOIL tab, you can observe that 8 hours is added, while the summary shows the actual hours worked on Saturday as 1 hour, along with the default 8 hours sent to TOIL.

Hence, the same scenario can be used for Sunday's, Non-Working Days and Holiday's too

Thank you for reading! 😎
I hope this Blog provided valuable insights into unique Time Valuation. Feel free to share your thoughts, questions, or experiences in the comments below. Stay tuned for more SAP content!

entry.title: Re: Block shipment for certain time
entry.content:
Not sure whether this requirement is a regular requirement or an one-time requirement. If your requirement is just to block the stock, one simple and straight forward approach would be to create a delivery and save it so that the delivery quantity cannot be used for any other sales order.

If you also want to block shipment creation for two weeks, what you can do is after backflush, move HU-managed stock to a non-ship storage location or blocked stock. Create a batch job or MIGO movement to transfer stock back to the shipping location after 2 weeks. Advantage of going with this options are it physically prevents picking and shipment and works well with HU-managed locations. But on the other side, it requires additional stock movement logic and may need custom automation or manual intervention.

entry.title: Using List of Values in Document AI to classify documents and other validation tasks
entry.content:
Document AI (also known as Document Information Extraction previously) helps you to process large number of business documents of various layouts.

With the advancement of Generative AI and LLM, Document AI can now process various document types and more complex documents. Thanks to the support for list of values data type, it's more versatile than you might expect.

Let’s take a quick tour of what’s possible — and maybe spark some ideas for your next project.

Prerequisites:

  • Subscription to Document AI (Premium Edition)

 

Document Classification

Let’s say you’ve got a stack of documents — invoices, contracts, shipping receipts, and tax forms. Normally, sorting them would take hours.

With Document AI and natural language prompting, you can now say:

“Classify this document as one of: [‘CertificateOfCompliance’, ‘DeliveryOrder’, ServiceReport']”

The clearer the prompts, the better the results.

The following shows an example of a schema that used list of values to classify documents.

 

 

 

 

 

 

You can add a total of 20 values here for this data type.

 

Extension

I applied Document AI’s list of values feature to detect the presence of signatures within documents. While signature detection wasn’t the primary objective, leveraging this approach helps automate a key part of document validation.

The example below uses list of values to determine if there’s a signature.

 

To bring everything together, I created a custom schema that performs two key tasks: detecting the presence of a signature and classifying the document type. For this demonstration, I used a sample Certificate of Compliance. The model successfully identified that a signature was present and classified the document as a Certificate of Compliance. The output below illustrates the results.

 

Now Supports More Languages!

A major upgrade to Document AI is its expanding multilingual support. Now, you can extract, classify, and analyze documents written not just in English, but also in languages like Malay, Spanish, French, Japanese, and more.

 

In this post, I introduced how to leverage Document AI’s list of values feature to enhance your projects. . While signature detection wasn’t the primary objective, this use case highlights the flexibility and potential of combining structured schemas with prompting. There’s plenty of room to expand on this approach for more advanced document processing tasks.

 

See also:

  • Tutorials:
    • Setup BTP Trial Account
    • Setup Document AI in BTP Trial Account
  • List of values data type
  • Supported Languages

entry.title: Re: how create validation for OSPP table -HANA DB
entry.content:
At first glance, I think the problem is value of primary key. You should have CardCode ItemCode with space, not ItemCode CardCode without space. So try putting

("CardCode" || ' ' || "ItemCode")

instead of ("ItemCode"||"CardCode")

Usually in such situations when I am not sure how to set up parameters in stored procedure, I use this code that blocks every transaction and gives me exact parameter values:

begin
               error := 1;
               error_message := N'Block object ' || object_type || ', transaction ' || transaction_type
               	|| ', key ' || list_of_cols_val_tab_del || ', key num ' || num_of_cols_in_key || ', key list ' || list_of_key_cols_tab_del;
               end;
